data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: The internal structure that protects and supports the soft organs, tissues, and other parts of a vertebrate organism, and is composed of bone and cartilage or, in certain animals, cartilage alone.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: The hard external structure that supports, protects, or contains the body of many invertebrates, such as mollusks, crustaceans, and corals, and certain vertebrates, such as turtles.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A supporting structure or framework, as of a building.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Something reduced to its basic or minimal parts.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: One that is very thin or emaciated.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A sport in which a person glides down an icy track head-first lying on one's stomach on a compact, simple sled that lacks steering or brakes.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: The sled used in such a sport.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
